The 2 metrics are:

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Fixing ToKiloFormat method" (#7266) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "Azure Search performance seems worse than Catalog to Lucene against packages with many versions" (#7265) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Earlier today I ran a test on DEV by bulk updating 10,000 versions of a package with 10,000 versions.

The results looked roughly like this:
![image.png](https://images.zenhubusercontent.com/58054e1495e42b6c5baa9ebb/16cd1ca3-68eb-4f37-8bfc-6ddbf242e0ef)

(Db2Catalog's cursor is off-screen, but it started running at 22:10.)

As you can see, Global finished in roughly 30 minutes and China finished in roughly 75.

Global Catalog2Registration took roughly 14 minutes to finish.
Global Catalog2AzureSearch took roughly 8-12 minutes to finish.

China Catalog2Registration took roughly 11 minutes to finish.
China Catalog2AzureSearch took roughly 36-38 minutes to finish!!!

In the past, Catalog2Lucene performed much better against these bulk update events, taking only 5-6 minutes on both regions. Additionally, the slowness of China Catalog2AzureSearch seems extremely suspicious.

Ideally, Catalog2AzureSearch should perform just as fast as Catalog2Lucene did.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Reference metadata is not preserved if NuGet packages add duplicate Framework Reference" (#8238) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Metadata on `Reference` items is lost if the references are replaced by a reference from a NuGet package.  For example, in a .NET 4.7.2 project with the following:

```xml
<ItemGroup>
    <Reference Include="System.Net.Http" Aliases="snh" />
    <PackageReference Include="System.Net.Http" Version="4.1.0" />
</ItemGroup>
```

And with the following code:

```c#
extern alias snh;
using System;

class Program
{
    static void Main(string[] args)
    {
        var client = new snh::System.Net.Http.HttpClient();
    }
}
```

Will fail to build, because NuGet will try to replace the `Reference` to System.Net.Http with the version of that DLL that comes from the NuGet package, and the Aliases information is lost.  This happens here: 

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.BuildTasks/blob/640c8e13a9b7ab6e86264a296638fbf3cc016ad1/src/Microsoft.NuGet.Build.Tasks/Microsoft.NuGet.targets#L209-L210

Conflict resolution comes along later and replaces the NuGet reference with a simple name reference again, but by that time the Aliases metadata is gone.

There are currently several ways that references can flow and get replaced, losing this metadata.  I am planning to fix some of them in this PR: https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/pull/3331

The changes in that PR, together with deleting the referenced line from Microsoft.NuGet.targets, make this scenario work.  That may be the right fix.  It will result in multiple references to System.Net.Http (one a simple reference and one in the NuGet package), but ResolvePackageFileConflicts should choose the right one.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet pack is including everything in my project directory" (#8237) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
My environment is as follows:

NuGet version: 4.9.3.5777
Visual Studio 2017
Windows 7 Pro x64

I am running *NuGet* during my build process because I have to. This is in a project that has a dependency against ``xunit.core``, which does not want to be built via conventional nor contemporary build steps. So I am finding that I must furnish my own ``nuspec`` to workaround that issue.

Anyway, the assets I want to include are simply these:

```Xml
<files>
  <file src="my.assembly.*" target="lib\netstandard1.1" />
</files>
```

The assembly targets ``netstandard1.1``, and I want to include the *DLL*, *XML*, and possibly also the *PDB*.

I am literally running ``NuGet`` via a *Build Target*,

```Xml
<Exec Command="nuget pack "$(MSBuildProjectName).nuspec" -OutputDirectory "bin\$(Configuration)" -Properties Configuration=$(Configuration)"/>
```

That's it. Nothing fancy about that.

However, *NuGet* is trying to package ***ALL*** the files from my project. It is completely ignoring the ``nuspec`` file.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Question: Does the order of package entries inside packages.config matter?" (#8216) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
If someone were to reorder the list of packages in the packages.config XML does this have any impact on how the project rebuilds or anything?

I want to order the packages alphabetically in two related but different applications so we can see the (few) differences more easily when we look at the files.

```
ExtractPackageAsync_RequireMode_EmptyRepoAllowList_ErrorAsync
ExtractPackageAsync_RequireMode_NoMatchInClientAllowList_ErrorAsync
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Package Manager Console:  UI delay updating "Default project" combobox selected value" (#8235) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Internal bug 634844.

Package Manager Console updates its "Default project" combobox selected value synchronously by transitioning to the main thread, fetching the default project --- which may block on building NuGet's project cache ---, and then getting the name of the project.  This operation can incur significant UI delays, especially during solution load of a large solution.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Installing a DotnetPlatform package locally" (#8234) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: `nuget.exe`

NuGet version:  5.0.2.5988

dotnet.exe --version : 2.1.602

VS version: 2019

OS version: Windows 10 1809 (17763.557)

Worked before? No

1. Run the command to install package locally from the CLI:

```powershell
.\nuget.exe install 'Microsoft.AspNetCore.App.Ref' -Version 3.0.0-preview5-19227-01
```

Notice that the process will fail with:

```powershell
Error NU5000: Package 'Microsoft.AspNetCore.App.Ref 3.0.0-preview5-19227-01' has a package type 'DotnetPlatform' that is not supported by project 'C:\bin'.
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Complete 5.2.0.6045 Toolset Insertion" (#8229) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Complete 5.2.0.6045 CLI Insertion" (#8228) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "nuget list & add commands are being deprecated in 5.0" (#34) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Tracking Issue(s):
* Deprecate ambiguous nuget.exe commands in 5.0 [#7753](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7753)
  * Deprecate nuget.exe add command [#7923](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7923)
  * Rename nuget.exe list to nuget.exe search [#7912](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7912)

The following commands are being deprecated because these are cause of confusion due to their nomenclature and/or other related commands that already exist:
* [`nuget list`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-list): Currently displays a list of packages from a given source
  * This will be replaced by an equivalent command **`nuget search`** which will be later enhanced with more capabilities as we make progress with or [search improvements](nvmd got it: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6371​​​​​​​).
* [`nuget add`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-add): Currently adds a specified package to a non-HTTP package source (a folder or UNC path) in a hierarchical layout, wherein folders are created for the package ID and version number. 
  * This will be replaced by overloading **`nuget push`** command.

> These commands will be deprecated i.e. there will be a warning on usage of these commands in 5.0 so that in future releases these commands can be discontinued.
